Award.AwardTitle: The Dynamics of Jets and Waves in the Atmosphere and Southern Ocean
Award.AbstractNarration: The results of this project will help to reduce the uncertainties in long-term climate prediction of the global-scale surface temperature and circulation patterns. Two high school teachers with backgrounds in advanced earth science and computer science, and two high school students will engage with the team to use and analyze climate science data sets. The scientific objectives of this project are to advance knowledge of (1) how mid latitude waves and jets are linked to tropical and high-latitude processes, and (2) how the atmospheric jet variability influences Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC), jets, eddies, and jet-scale overturning circulations. For the first objective, the investigation will be focused on how poleward heat transport by atmospheric waves is influenced by tropical heating and the background state of the atmosphere. The improved knowledge of the underlying physical processes can enhance understanding of the general circulation of both the atmosphere and the Southern Ocean. In addition, this knowledge can help us to evaluate how high-latitude surface temperatures and the Southern Ocean circulation, two of the most sensitive aspects of climate variability, respond to external forcings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There were two objectives in the project. The first objective was to advance our knowledge of how weather systems in mid-latitudes, particularly the jet streams and storms, interact with weather and climate conditions in the tropics and in the Arctic. Understanding the mechanisms behind these interactions is important for several reasons. In the tropics, the weather systems change in a less chaotic manner than in mid-latitudes. Also, the tropics occupy 50% of the Earth surface area. For these and other reasons, weather and climate conditions in the tropics often impact weather and climate in the mid-latitudes and the Arctic. This tropical influence provides an excellent opportunity to improve weather and climate forecast skill. In order to exploit the prediction potential, it is imperative to understand the underlying mechanisms by which tropical weather/climate conditions influence extra-tropical weather and climate.

The second objective was to improve our understanding of how atmospheric conditions influence the state of the ocean, roughly within the latitude belts bounded by Australia and Antarctica. That part of the world ocean plays a crucial role in regulating global climate by transporting and sequestering vast quantities of heat and carbon absorbed from the atmosphere. The key gateway to this sequestration is the air-sea exchange of heat and carbon through the so-called ocean mixed layer, yet little is known about how these mixed layers vary in response to changes in atmospheric conditions. It has been shown through climate model simulations and observations for some time that what is known as the Southern Annular Mode (SAM), the dominant pattern of large-scale variability in the Southern Hemisphere extratropics, has underwent a decadal time-scale changes in part caused by increased greenhouse gas loading in the atmosphere. Specifically, the eastward blowing winds in the Southern Hemisphere have been shifting toward Antarctica. From ocean circulation theories, this change in the wind system is expected to cause the ocean circulation to change, including the ocean mixed layer.  For this reason, the Southern Ocean response to the SAM has been the focus of much scientific research effort over the past two decades. Thus far most of the research employed numerical models with relatively coarse horizontal resolution, too coarse to resolve the energetically active swirling motion of oceanic eddies, typically less than about 100 km in size. For this NSF project, the researchers analyzed output from a high-resolution numerical ocean model which can resolve at least part of these eddies. The first and the second objectives are related to each other because the underlying dynamical mechanisms of the eddies and jets share much similarities between the atmosphere and the ocean, and by analyzing both systems, more insights can be gained.

Planetary-scale waves, whose wave length is typically greater than the earth radius, have been regarded as being unimportant for transporting heat from lower latitudes to the Arctic. However, our findings indicate that these waves are far more important than shorter weather-scale waves that have been believed to be critical in transporting heat into the Arctic.  We also showed that an anomalously strong equator-to-pole temperature gradient, which can be translated to potential energy that fuels atmospheric motions, is not required to excite these highly effective planetary waves.  Instead, these waves are typically excited by latent heating caused by deep moist convection (resulting in tall clouds) over the tropical western Pacific. These findings raise some fundamental questions on the widely accepted view – the perceived dominance of local ice-albedo-evaporation feedback where melting sea ice and snow by greenhouse gas warming allows more absorption of sunlight, further promoting the melting ice and snow. Previous studies showed that the extratropical planetary scale waves are forced by atmospheric heating in both the tropics and extra-tropics, among others. The findings from this NSF project shows that the extratropical heating is not independent of tropical heating because the former tends to be organized by waves that are driven by tropical heating. The result suggests that more accurate observations and modeling of the tropical convection is critical for improving the accuracy of weather and climate predictions.

Regarding the second objective, the findings from this NSF project show for the first time the mechanism by which the fall season mixed layer depth (MLD) in the Southern Ocean responds to the previous spring’s atmospheric SAM. The spring SAM – fall MLD relationship is a manifestation of the reemergence of interior water mass anomalies that had been established during the spring time when the SAM signal is strong.

 

The results from this NSF award have been disseminated through 11 peer-review journal articles, 13 conference contributed presentations, and 12 invited presentations in various universities, government labs, and conferences. This NSF award also supported three graduate students’ research activities at various stages, and helped two rural high school teachers to engage in research and disseminate the learning by developing new course materials.
